name: Aarushi
comment info:
Notice:
Looking at the graph, I notice that the southern states seem to have some of the "largest" fingerprints out of all the states, and also pertain to a higher overall level of concern in vaccination status. The smaller fingerprints tend to belong more to the northern states, along with the overall lower level of concern. Going more in depth, the green states(low concern) have a relatively small fingerprint, but a few of the states have spikes in specific variables. The pink states(high concern) have a more circular and well-rounded shape, with equal data in almost every variable for most of its states.

Wonder:
The map shows us a distinctly split status of the states- northern states having less concern in vaccination, while southern states are struggling with a much higher concern. I wonder if this has to do with economic statuses, or bigger populations all in all. Are there too many people to have proper healthcare, or is it a matter of social behavior?

Impact to community:
From the data, Virginia is shown to have a typically less-concerning vaccination barrier issue, but has a big spike for the variable "Low Health Care". Other than this, Virginia seems to be on a good path to vaccination, with less overall barriers in the process. In a nation-wide mindset, southern states are struggling to get vaccinated- it will be harder in the big picture to go back to "normal", and to maintain a decreasing case count.

Headline:
 "Vaccination Barriers- A Roadblock to Normality".

name: Joseph Mendoza
comment info: I notice that this is a graph informing us of the barriers to rapid vaccination by state in the United States. I can see that many states in the south are purple, meaning they are high risk, and tend to have the most barriers to the Covid-19 vaccine. Many of those states suffer from socioeconomic barriers, low health care, poor health access, and irregular medical care. I can also see that many states in the north also struggle with socioeconomic barriers primarily, but they are marked blue for low risk areas. I wonder as to why it is that we see much more concern and lack of medical care in the south than we do in the north. My first guess would be that the Northeast specifically has always excelled in medical advancements and medical care -- so it makes sense that they are doing well distributing coronavirus vaccines. My second guess is that the southern states tend to be very Republican leaning, and many people who are Republican are hesitant towards getting the vaccine. 1). When first observing the following graphic, there is a trend of Southern states facing greater vaccination barriers, all of which are rooted in health care problems or generalized poverty. name: Aeryn
comment info:
I notice that most states in the south have a high level of concern and high levels of each barrier point (a wider area of the illustrated shape). This is in contrast to most northern states, which have relatively low levels of concern and lower lengths of each point, or at least minimal lengths on most points with one outstanding point. 
I wonder if political ideals play into which states have lower or higher levels of concern, as well as which states have more barriers. Seeing as southern states (relatively more conservative states) have high levels of concern whereas more liberal states (OR, CA, WA, NY, etc) have lower levels of concern and fewer barriers. Is this tied to liberal vs conservative health policies in each state?
Living in Oregon, it looks like our heaviest barriers are low health care resources, historic undervaccination, and irregular medical care. Knowing many people who cannot afford health care or doctors visits, this makes sense to me. I am worried for our community, especially our high houseless population, who are more at risk due to the inability to use healthcare resources. I also know several immunocompromised people who are banking on herd immunity to save them, but when so many people are historically unvaccinated this may not be a safe bet.
Headline: "COVID Vaccines: A Question of State Healthcare Politics"

name: Grace U, Kaitlin B, Evan D, Brian S
comment info:
Kaitlin Bryhn, Grace Urban, Evan Divine, and Brian Samuel

The data presented in these graphs led to severing findings that our group noticed. The first thing we found was that the East coast has relatively low concern levels for vaccination barriers. However, New York, Pennsylvania, and Rhode Island share similar concerns for social economic barriers. We also noticed that there are more vaccination barriers in the Southern states. Our own state of Minnesota has a relatively low level of concern. We also wondered why there is such a great divide between the North and the South in vaccination barriers? Could this be a result of certain regions being prioritized for vaccination over other states and what impact does that have on vaccination barriers? Access to vaccinations plays a major role in ensuring that the entire community can be healthy and safe amidst this pandemic. In Minnesota, vaccination access is much better than many other states, although the greatest barrier is low health care resources. Depending on which state you live in, this will affect the role the government plays in mandating policies to curb the spread and distribute vaccinations. Lastly, if your state has a low level of concern, restrictions might be limited and the community might open up sooner. We would title this article, “America’s grasp on vaccines: Vaccination barriers and their fingerprints.”

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s radar graphs show the barriers for rapid, widespread vaccination by state and the summarized overall level of concern by state.  If you go to the New York Times article “What Are the Vaccine Roadblocks Where You Live?, you can enter your county and see the barriers for your community.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and “What impact does this topic have on you and your community?”  

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in these graphs. We will publish in Friday’s Reveal some of the on-target and catchiest headlines.

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the article that included these graphs and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”

View our archives that link to all past releases, organized by topic (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTopicIndex),
